q: What is high blood sugar?
a: High blood sugar (hyperglycaemia) is where the level of sugar in your blood is too high. It mainly affects people with diabetes and can be serious if not treated.

q: What is low blood sugar?
a: Low blood sugar (hypoglycaemia) is when the level of sugar in your blood is too low. This can also affect people with diabetes.

q: How can you find out if your blood sugar level is high?
i: You can find out if your blood sugar level is high by having a blood sugar (blood glucose) test.
a: You can find out if your blood sugar level is high by having a blood sugar (blood glucose) test.

q: What are the symptoms of high blood sugar?
a: Symptoms of high blood sugar include feeling very thirsty, urinating a lot, feeling weak or tired, blurred vision, and losing weight.

q: What are the causes of high blood sugar in people with diabetes?
a: Common causes of high blood sugar in people with diabetes include being unwell, feeling stressed, eating too much sugary or starchy food, being less active than usual, missing doses of diabetes medicine, or if your diabetes medicine is not working well or you're taking certain medicines.

q: How can you lower your blood sugar?
i: To lower your blood sugar, you can take any diabetes medicine you've been prescribed, avoid eating too much sugary or starchy food, manage stress, exercise regularly, lose weight if you're overweight, and follow advice from your doctor or care team.
a: To lower your blood sugar, you can take any diabetes medicine you've been prescribed, avoid eating too much sugary or starchy food, manage stress, exercise regularly, lose weight if you're overweight, and follow advice from your doctor or care team.

q: When should you speak to your care team or GP if you have high blood sugar?
a: You should speak to your care team or GP if you have tried to lower your blood sugar but it is still high or if you have symptoms of high blood sugar and have not been diagnosed with diabetes.

q: What problems can be caused by high blood sugar?
a: High blood sugar can cause problems such as peripheral neuropathy (damage to the nerves in your hands and feet), diabetic retinopathy (damage to your eyes and problems with your sight), and life-threatening conditions such as diabetic ketoacidosis.

q: What should you do if you think you have high blood sugar and experience certain symptoms?
i: If you think you have high blood sugar and experience symptoms such as feeling sick, stomach pain, rapid breathing, drowsiness, fruity breath, confusion, or high level of ketones in your blood or pee, you should call your care team immediately or get help from NHS 111.
a: If you think you have high blood sugar and experience symptoms such as feeling sick, stomach pain, rapid breathing, drowsiness, fruity breath, confusion, or high level of ketones in your blood or pee, you should call your care team immediately or get help from NHS 111.

i: If you have diabetes, you can find out if your blood sugar level is high by having a blood sugar (blood glucose) test.

q: What are the symptoms of high blood sugar?
a: Symptoms of high blood sugar include feeling very thirsty, frequent urination, feeling weak or tired, blurred vision, and weight loss.

q: What are the common causes of high blood sugar in people with diabetes?
a: Common causes of high blood sugar in people with diabetes include being unwell, feeling stressed, eating too much sugary or starchy food, being less active than usual, missing doses of diabetes medicine, or taking certain medicines (such as steroids).

q: How can you lower your blood sugar?
a: To lower your blood sugar, it's important to take prescribed diabetes medicine, avoid consuming excessive sugary or starchy food, manage stress, exercise regularly, maintain a healthy weight, and follow advice from your doctor or care team.

q: When should you speak to your care team or GP surgery regarding high blood sugar?
a: You should speak to your care team or GP surgery if you have tried to lower your blood sugar but it remains high, or if you have symptoms of high blood sugar and have not been diagnosed with diabetes.

q: What problems can be caused by high blood sugar?
a: High blood sugar can lead to complications such as peripheral neuropathy (nerve damage in hands and feet), diabetic retinopathy (eye damage), and life-threatening conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis.

q: When should you seek urgent advice for high blood sugar?
a: You should seek urgent advice from your care team or call NHS 111 if you experience symptoms such as feeling sick, stomach pain, rapid breathing or increased heart rate, drowsiness or difficulty staying awake, fruity-smelling breath, confusion or difficulty concentrating, or a high level of ketones in your blood or urine.

q: What is the significance of a high level of ketones in the blood or urine?
a: A high level of ketones in the blood or urine is a sign of diabetic ketoacidosis, a life-threatening condition associated with high blood sugar.

q: What are the symptoms of high blood sugar?
a: Common symptoms of high blood sugar include feeling very thirsty, frequent urination, feeling weak or tired, blurred vision, and weight loss.

q: What are the common causes of high blood sugar in people with diabetes?
a: Common causes of high blood sugar in people with diabetes include being unwell, feeling stressed, eating too much sugary or starchy food, being less active than usual, and missing doses of diabetes medicine.

q: How can I lower my blood sugar?
a: If you have diabetes, you can lower your blood sugar by taking your prescribed diabetes medicine, avoiding eating too much sugary or starchy food, managing stress, exercising regularly, losing weight if overweight, and following advice from your doctor or care team while you're ill.

q: When should I speak to my care team or GP surgery about high blood sugar?
a: You should speak to your care team or GP surgery if you have tried to lower your blood sugar but it remains high or if you have symptoms of high blood sugar and have not been diagnosed with diabetes.

q: What problems can high blood sugar cause?
a: If high blood sugar persists or reaches a very high level, it can lead to complications such as permanent damage to the nerves in your hands and feet, damage to your eyes and vision problems, and life-threatening conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis.

q: What should I do if I think I have high blood sugar and experience certain symptoms?
a: If you think you have high blood sugar and experience symptoms such as feeling sick, stomach pain, rapid breathing, drowsiness, fruity breath smell, confusion, difficulty concentrating, or high levels of ketones in your blood or urine, you should call your care team immediately or seek help from NHS 111.

q: How can I test for ketones if I have high blood sugar?
a: If you have high blood sugar, your doctor or care team may ask you to test your blood or urine for ketones, as a high level of ketones is a sign of diabetic ketoacidosis.

q: What are the types of diabetes tests for assessing high blood sugar levels?
a: Types of diabetes tests for assessing high blood sugar levels include the HbA1c test, which checks your blood sugar level over the last few months, and fasting glucose test, which is done after not eating for a few hours. Home tests can also be done after waking up or at any other time.

q: What blood sugar levels are considered high?
a: Blood sugar levels are considered high if they are over 7 mmol/L for a fasting glucose test and over 11 mmol/L for a home test at any other time. HbA1c levels of 48 mmol/mol or over (6.5% if given as a percentage) also indicate high blood sugar.

q: Are blood sugar level targets the same for everyone with diabetes?
a: No, blood sugar level targets may vary depending on factors like age and the type of diabetes. It is important to check with your doctor or care team to determine the appropriate targets for your individual case.
